turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think you have a moment or so, Mr. Ringold.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

Mr. Justice Whittaker, in response to a question concerning the necessity or the right to a hearing, it was our opinion that this statute in this particular situation deprived the plaintiffs of a hearing.

For that reason, at its inception, our complaint was drawn on that basis and paragraph 5 of our complaint as it appears on page 2 of the printed record, upon they did execute such oath, his employment be terminated.
Thereupon, there was a denial by the State.
Request for admissions were made which admitted that the statute would be construed in that fashion to deny a hearing.
The findings of fact in conclusions of law, conclusion, Finding of Fact number 6 was then included.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You say there was a stipulation in the trial below that -- to the effect that that he would not be -- these people would not be accorded a hearing.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Request for admission were made and in -- and the findings of fact were based upon the answers to the requests for admissions.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I thought you said --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- from the matter of stipulation just a moment ago.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I said their answers, Mr. Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: -- to our request for admissions, indicated that a hearing would not be granted.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you remember what the number of that, Mr. Ringold?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I do not believe that is in the printed record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But it --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I would have to go through --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Number 5?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Two or five.
In any event --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: In any event --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Let me ask you this, Mr. Ringold.
In your brief, you state that -- that the 1955 law repealed that portion of the law which -- which accorded a hearing.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: This --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, and Mr. Fuller says that that law as it set out on -- on page 67, 68 of his brief is still a law and that such a hearing can be held.
Will you tell us why there is that difference of opinion between you and what you base it on?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: The question I assume, Mr. Chief Justice, depended upon whether or not a review by implication took place or not.
This was why we interpreted as a review by implication having taken place by virtue of the 1955 Act.
And again, that was why we framed the complaint originally to specifically raise the question.
And this matter was argued in the lower court, it was argued in the Supreme Court of the State of Washington.
We of course extensively argued it with respect to the Attorney General's list.
We did raise the question with respect to a -- we -- we cited Slochower and those other matters.
Then when the original opinion of the Supreme Court came down, the focal point then, it became much more pointed as to whether or not the hearing issue was raised.
And in our petition for rehearing, pages 41 to 45 of the unprinted record, we specifically raise the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did you say?
And could you just read us a sentence or two to see that --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The Wyman case clearly establish that public employment was not a privilege which could be denied for any reason whatsoever.
The United States Supreme Court's unanimous holding was that eligibility for public employment can only be conditioned on requirements which had a reasonable relation to fitness.
The importance of this aspect of our argument was totally overlooked by this Court in its failure to mention and apply the doctrine of Swayze, Schwer, Canniburgh, Slochower.
It is --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I am reading from the unprinted --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: This is our petition for rehearing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you can leave that with us, can't you?
Or else I should --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: It is in the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- the other side would agree to this.
(Inaudible)if they agreed to this.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes, it is in the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do we have that --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- for rehearing?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Black.
It is no answer to say Learner Dylan and Adler.
Each of these cases involved hearings to determine the fitness of the employee for employment under the state's right to investigate the qualifications of the employees.
And then we underlined.

"There is not one case decided by the Supreme Court of the United States which holds that the State may discharge an employee solely upon refusal to subscribe to an oath that he is not a subversive person."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Am I -- am I wrong, as I read complete through your 86-paged brief in the Supreme Court too hurriedly to have missed that you discussed this opinion in that brief.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Page 35 of our brief, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Under what heading does that come?
And just with the -- the heading, thinking that the heading --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Under due process.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The first point was the hearing as to the nature of the organization, is that right?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Court please, page 35 of the respondent's brief in the Supreme Court of the State of Washington.
In Slochower versus Board or Education's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is the heading under which this appears?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: The heading under which it appeared is under due process that scienter is a necessary element in oaths of nonmembership in proscribed organizations.
We then cited Slochower.

The plaintiff claimed this privilege, we quoted Mr. Justice Clark, then we said the Court discusses Adler Garner and then says, “But in each of these cases, it was emphasized that the State must conform to the requirements of due process.
The summary dismissal of appellant violates due process of law.”
This is emphasized, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think that's the discussion of the requirement of a hearing?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I -- well, we certainly felt it was.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, maybe -- maybe it was.
All I said was when I saw --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: We --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the headings that scienter was required, I didn't think I'd find under it a discussion of hearing that may --

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I am sorry, Mr. Justice Brennan.
This was one of them, and in their -- I think there were others and I don't have them before me now.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: My recollection was that after the admissions were made, an argument was had before the trial court, I prepared the findings of fact and the conclusions of law and they were presented to the Attorney General's office.
They incorporated finding number 6, they were approved and in -- in accordance with the original complaint which initiated the action.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, your arguments would not -- before the trial court, your arguments or the other side's arguments?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: There were.
We presented a written brief and the state's Attorney General --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are they in the record?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: They are not, You Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are they available?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: I believe they are.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would each of you supply us with -- with your briefs, please, a copy of your brief?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, we will, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We have your brief in the record, but I do not think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Not the trial court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not the trial court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, no because that means --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it their briefs in the trial court?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but even beyond.
In the Supreme Court, we have the appellant brief, but we do not have the state's brief, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The state wasn't a company --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the State have a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The State of the appellant in the Supreme Court of -- of --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And we do not --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We do not have that.
We do have the -- the present appellant's brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Yes.
The --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you supply that too, please, Mr. Fuller?

turn.speaker: herbert_h_fuller
turn.label: Mr. Herbert H. Fuller
turn.text: I will, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: The state's brief in the State Supreme Court only argued the state constitutional issues, did not argue the federal constitutional issues which had been raised.
They were the appellants --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What you had advanced (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: We'll do so, Mr. Justice Brennan.
May I just mention, our brief in opposition to the motion to dismiss, I think that we discussed that.
A motion to dismiss was made upon this precise ground.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: solie_m_ringold
turn.label: Mr. Solie M. Ringold
turn.text: Thank you.
